content: Information about extinct North American Bears

chosen:
Here are some extinct North American bears:
- Short Faced Bear (Arctodus simus) - lived from the middle of the Pleistocene epoch (about 500,000 years ago) to the end of the last glacial period, about 10,000 years ago. It was a very large bear, with an estimated body length of up to 3 meters (9 feet).
- Giant Short Faced Bear (Arctodus gigas) - lived from the late Pleistocene epoch (about 2 million years ago) to the early Holocene epoch (about 6,000 years ago). Its body may have measured up to 4 meters (13 feet).
- Cave Bear (Ursus spelaeus) - lived from the Middle Pleistocene epoch (about 781,000 to 126,000 years ago) to the early Holocene epoch (about 6,000 years ago). It was a medium-sized bear, with an estimated body length of up to 2.5 meters (8 feet).

Some brown bear populations are now extinct, due to hunting in the early 19th and 20th century. They include the California grizzly bear, the Mexican grizzly bear and the Ungava brown bear.
rejected:
- Giant Short-faced Bear (Arctodus simus) - Lived from the middle of the Pleistocene epoch (about 500,000 years ago) to the end of the last ice age.
- Cave Bear (Ursus spelaeus) - Lived in Europe during the Pleistocene epoch.
- Brown Bear (Ursus arctos) - Still exists today.
